00023 #include <avr/io.h>
00024 #include "settings.h"

00037 // Execute linear motion in absolute millimeter coordinates. Feed rate given in millimeters/second
00038 // unless invert_feed_rate is true. Then the feed_rate means that the motion should be completed in
00039 // (1 minute)/feed_rate time.
00040 // NOTE: This is the primary gateway to the grbl planner. All line motions, including arc line
00041 // segments, must pass through this routine before being passed to the planner. The seperation of
00042 // mc_line and plan_buffer_line is done primarily to make backlash compensation integration simple
00043 // and direct.
00044 // TODO: Check for a better way to avoid having to push the arguments twice for non-backlash cases.
00045 // However, this keeps the memory requirements lower since it doesn't have to call and hold two
00046 // plan_buffer_lines in memory. Grbl only has to retain the original line input variables during a
00047 // backlash segment(s).
00048 void mc_line(double x, double y, double z, double a, double feed_rate, uint8_t invert_feed_rate)
00049 {
00050   // TODO: Backlash compensation may be installed here. Only need direction info to track when
00051   // to insert a backlash line motion(s) before the intended line motion. Requires its own
00052   // plan_check_full_buffer() and check for system abort loop. Also for position reporting
00053   // backlash steps will need to be also tracked. Not sure what the best strategy is for this,
00054   // i.e. keep the planner independent and do the computations in the status reporting, or let
00055   // the planner handle the position corrections. The latter may get complicated.
00056 
00057   // If the buffer is full: good! That means we are well ahead of the robot.
00058   // Remain in this loop until there is room in the buffer.
00059   do {
00060     protocol_execute_runtime(); // Check for any run-time commands
00061     if (sys.abort) { return; } // Bail, if system abort.
00062   } while ( plan_check_full_buffer() );
00063   plan_buffer_line(x, y, z, a, feed_rate, invert_feed_rate);
00064 
00065   // Auto-cycle start immediately after planner finishes. Enabled/disabled by grbl settings. During
00066   // a feed hold, auto-start is disabled momentarily until the cycle is resumed by the cycle-start
00067   // runtime command.
00068   // NOTE: This is allows the user to decide to exclusively use the cycle start runtime command to
00069   // begin motion or let grbl auto-start it for them. This is useful when: manually cycle-starting
00070   // when the buffer is completely full and primed; auto-starting, if there was only one g-code
00071   // command sent during manual operation; or if a system is prone to buffer starvation, auto-start
00072   // helps make sure it minimizes any dwelling/motion hiccups and keeps the cycle going.
00073   if (sys.auto_start) { st_cycle_start(); }
00074 }
00075 
00076 
00077 // Execute an arc in offset mode format. position == current xyz, target == target xyz,
00078 // offset == offset from current xyz, axis_XXX defines circle plane in tool space, axis_linear is
00079 // the direction of helical travel, radius == circle radius, isclockwise boolean. Used
00080 // for vector transformation direction.
00081 // The arc is approximated by generating a huge number of tiny, linear segments. The length of each
00082 // segment is configured in settings.mm_per_arc_segment.
00083 void mc_arc(double *position, double *target, double *offset, uint8_t axis_0, uint8_t axis_1,
00084   uint8_t axis_linear, double feed_rate, uint8_t invert_feed_rate, double radius, uint8_t isclockwise)
00085 {
00086   double center_axis0 = position[axis_0] + offset[axis_0];
00087   double center_axis1 = position[axis_1] + offset[axis_1];
00088   double linear_travel = target[axis_linear] - position[axis_linear];
00089   double r_axis0 = -offset[axis_0];  // Radius vector from center to current location
00090   double r_axis1 = -offset[axis_1];
00091   double rt_axis0 = target[axis_0] - center_axis0;
00092   double rt_axis1 = target[axis_1] - center_axis1;
00093 
00094   // CCW angle between position and target from circle center. Only one atan2() trig computation required.
00095   double angular_travel = atan2(r_axis0*rt_axis1-r_axis1*rt_axis0, r_axis0*rt_axis0+r_axis1*rt_axis1);
00096   if (angular_travel < 0) { angular_travel += 2*M_PI; }
00097   if (isclockwise) { angular_travel -= 2*M_PI; }
00098 
00099   double millimeters_of_travel = hypot(angular_travel*radius, fabs(linear_travel));
00100   if (millimeters_of_travel == 0.0) { return; }
00101   uint16_t segments = floor(millimeters_of_travel/settings.mm_per_arc_segment);
00102   // Multiply inverse feed_rate to compensate for the fact that this movement is approximated
00103   // by a number of discrete segments. The inverse feed_rate should be correct for the sum of
00104   // all segments.
00105   if (invert_feed_rate) { feed_rate *= segments; }
00106 
00107   double theta_per_segment = angular_travel/segments;
00108   double linear_per_segment = linear_travel/segments;
00109 
00110   /* Vector rotation by transformation matrix: r is the original vector, r_T is the rotated vector,
00111      and phi is the angle of rotation. Based on the solution approach by Jens Geisler.
00112          r_T = [cos(phi) -sin(phi);
00113                 sin(phi)  cos(phi] * r ;
00114 
00115      For arc generation, the center of the circle is the axis of rotation and the radius vector is
00116      defined from the circle center to the initial position. Each line segment is formed by successive
00117      vector rotations. This requires only two cos() and sin() computations to form the rotation
00118      matrix for the duration of the entire arc. Error may accumulate from numerical round-off, since
00119      all double numbers are single precision on the Arduino. (True double precision will not have
00120      round off issues for CNC applications.) Single precision error can accumulate to be greater than
00121      tool precision in some cases. Therefore, arc path correction is implemented.
00122 
00123      Small angle approximation may be used to reduce computation overhead further. This approximation
00124      holds for everything, but very small circles and large mm_per_arc_segment values. In other words,
00125      theta_per_segment would need to be greater than 0.1 rad and N_ARC_CORRECTION would need to be large
00126      to cause an appreciable drift error. N_ARC_CORRECTION~=25 is more than small enough to correct for
00127      numerical drift error. N_ARC_CORRECTION may be on the order a hundred(s) before error becomes an
00128      issue for CNC machines with the single precision Arduino calculations.
00129 
00130      This approximation also allows mc_arc to immediately insert a line segment into the planner
00131      without the initial overhead of computing cos() or sin(). By the time the arc needs to be applied
00132      a correction, the planner should have caught up to the lag caused by the initial mc_arc overhead.
00133      This is important when there are successive arc motions.
00134   */
00135   // Vector rotation matrix values
00136   double cos_T = 1-0.5*theta_per_segment*theta_per_segment; // Small angle approximation
00137   double sin_T = theta_per_segment;
00138 
00139   double arc_target[3];
00140   double sin_Ti;
00141   double cos_Ti;
00142   double r_axisi;
00143   uint16_t i;
00144   int8_t count = 0;
00145 
00146   // Initialize the linear axis
00147   arc_target[axis_linear] = position[axis_linear];
00148 
00149   for (i = 1; i<segments; i++) { // Increment (segments-1)
00150 
00151     if (count < N_ARC_CORRECTION) {
00152       // Apply vector rotation matrix
00153       r_axisi = r_axis0*sin_T + r_axis1*cos_T;
00154       r_axis0 = r_axis0*cos_T - r_axis1*sin_T;
00155       r_axis1 = r_axisi;
00156       count++;
00157     } else {
00158       // Arc correction to radius vector. Computed only every N_ARC_CORRECTION increments.
00159       // Compute exact location by applying transformation matrix from initial radius vector(=-offset).
00160       cos_Ti = cos(i*theta_per_segment);
00161       sin_Ti = sin(i*theta_per_segment);
00162       r_axis0 = -offset[axis_0]*cos_Ti + offset[axis_1]*sin_Ti;
00163       r_axis1 = -offset[axis_0]*sin_Ti - offset[axis_1]*cos_Ti;
00164       count = 0;
00165     }
00166 
00167     // Update arc_target location
00168     arc_target[axis_0] = center_axis0 + r_axis0;
00169     arc_target[axis_1] = center_axis1 + r_axis1;
00170     arc_target[axis_linear] += linear_per_segment;
00171 /*
00172  TODO: Just bailing out on A or U, need to understand code better.
00173 */
00174     mc_line(arc_target[X_AXIS], arc_target[Y_AXIS], arc_target[Z_AXIS], 0, feed_rate, invert_feed_rate);
00175 
00176     // Bail mid-circle on system abort. Runtime command check already performed by mc_line.
00177     if (sys.abort) { return; }
00178   }
00179   // Ensure last segment arrives at target location.
00180   mc_line(target[X_AXIS], target[Y_AXIS], target[Z_AXIS], 0, feed_rate, invert_feed_rate);
00181 }
00182

00184 // Execute dwell in seconds.
00185 void mc_dwell(double seconds)
00186 {
00187    uint16_t i = floor(1000/DWELL_TIME_STEP*seconds);
00188    plan_synchronize();
00189    delay_ms(floor(1000*seconds-i*DWELL_TIME_STEP)); // Delay millisecond remainder
00190    while (i-- > 0) {
00191      // NOTE: Check and execute runtime commands during dwell every <= DWELL_TIME_STEP milliseconds.
00192      protocol_execute_runtime();
00193      if (sys.abort) { return; }
00194      _delay_ms(DWELL_TIME_STEP); // Delay DWELL_TIME_STEP increment
00195    }
00196 }

00199 // TODO: Update limits and homing cycle subprograms for better integration with new features.
00200 void mc_go_home()
00201 {
00202   limits_go_home();
00203   // Upon completion, reset all internal position vectors (g-code parser, planner, system)
00204   gc_clear_position();
00205   plan_clear_position();
00206   clear_vector_double(sys.position);
00207 }
